articles.title: JUNE 1988
articles.summary: This document details the San Jose Astronomical Association's calendar of events for June and July 1988. Activities include a general meeting featuring a talk on Gravity Probe-B, several field expeditions for astronomical observation to various state and county parks, and introductory astronomy classes. The schedule also highlights board meetings, an annual picnic, and public star parties.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: This article discusses two main topics: the Gravity Probe-B experiment, designed by Stanford and built by Lockheed for NASA, which aims to test Einstein's General Theory of Relativity using precision gyroscopes in space. It also details the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) annual Yosemite Star Party, a popular observing event scheduled for August 19-20, providing reservation instructions and highlighting the exceptional dark skies.

articles.title: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY HAS NEW HOTLINE NUMBER
articles.summary: The Astronomical Society of the Pacific's Astronomy News Hotline has a new number: 415-337-1244. This 24-hour recorded message, updated weekly by Sherwood Harrington, provides information on new astronomical discoveries, special sky events, and other topics of interest to astronomers. Operating since 1975, there is no surcharge for calling the hotline.

articles.title: A.S.P. SOLICITING NOMINATIONS FOR 1989 AMATEUR ACHIEVEMENT AWARD
articles.summary: The Astronomical Society of the Pacific (A.S.P.) is inviting nominations for its 1989 Amateur Achievement Award, an international honor that recognizes outstanding astronomical contributions by non-professionals and includes a plaque and $250 prize. Nominations, which require both a concise statement and a detailed description of the nominee's work, must be submitted to the A.S.P. by August 31, 1988.

articles.title: PRESIDENT'S MESSAGE TOM AHL - SJAA
articles.summary: This President's Message from Tom Ahl of SJAA reports on the successful National Astronomy Day held on April 23, 1988, at Branham Lane Park. The event featured numerous telescopes, observations of the sun and moon (including an occultation), and attracted between 50 and 75 attendees. The message thanks participating members and looks forward to expanding National Astronomy Day to multiple locations next year.

articles.title: REPORTER AT LARGE (+ CUB REPORTER)
articles.summary: At the April Board Meeting, the SJAA established a new 'Reporter-at-large' position, filled by Don Grabski, and a 'Cub Reporter-at-large' position, taken by Brian Zahring. Their duties include documenting club activities and gathering ideas and suggestions from members for future initiatives.

articles.title: SCHOOL STAR PARTY ACTIVITIES
articles.summary: An astronomy club has successfully conducted six school astronomy activities, including lectures and public observing sessions with telescopes, receiving overwhelmingly positive feedback. The club aims to continue making astronomy accessible to the public through star parties at schools, parks, and shopping centers, particularly anticipating Mars's close approach this fall. They are requesting volunteers to help contact local institutions to schedule more public observing sessions and spread enthusiasm for astronomy.

articles.title: AN OVERVIEW OF OBSERVING SITES BY: DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE
articles.summary: This article provides a detailed overview of Henry Coe State Park as an astronomy observing site, highlighting its dark skies and various options for astronomers. It includes practical information such as directions, specific site descriptions (including a dedicated star party hill and the "Overflow Lot"), costs, light pollution concerns, elevation, and available facilities. The park offers both designated star party areas and options for individual observing or camping.

articles.title: JUNE STARRY NIGHTS BY RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: Richard Stanton's "June Starry Nights" outlines celestial events for June, highlighting the minor Tau Herculids meteor shower peaking on the 3rd and the Summer Solstice on June 21st UT. The article provides observation details for three minor planets (21 Lutetia, 43 Ariadne, and 2 Pallas) and notes specific lunar terminator events on the Straight Wall and Plato. It briefly mentions Saturn as an enchanting object for observers.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article provides an update on comet visibility, noting Comet Liller and Periodic Comet Temple 2 are currently observable. No new comets have been discovered, but Periodic Comet Finlay (1988f) was recovered by A. Gilmore and P. Kilmartin, though it is faint (magnitude 17) and not expected to exceed magnitude 13 due to its unfavorable position near the sun.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This article provides detailed ephemerides for two comets, Comet Liller (1988a) and Periodic Comet Tempel 2 (1987g), covering their positions, elongations, and magnitudes from late May through early July. It notes that Comet Liller is still visible despite being past perihelion, while Comet Tempel 2 is expected to brighten significantly by mid-September, becoming a binocular object. The data assists observers in locating and tracking these comets.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article provides a statistical analysis of comet discoveries from 1759 to 1988d, noting that 779 comets have been named, primarily after 326 unique individuals. It highlights prolific discoverers like Jean Pons (26 comets) and offers interesting facts about shared names and letter frequency among discoverers. The document also includes a brief observing report about Saturn's upcoming opposition in June.

articles.title: THE PRETORIA EYEPIECE - again! BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article provides an update on the Pretoria eyepiece, clarifying its utility beyond fast Newtonian telescopes. Originally thought to be limited, the eyepiece is now recommended for use in virtually all telescopes, as it corrects coma rather than introducing negative coma. The article also introduces a related 3x compensating Barlow lens designed to improve high-power performance in fast scopes.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document, titled "ASTRO ADS," features classified advertisements for used astronomical equipment. Various telescopes like the C-90 Spotting Scope, Celestron 8, and 10-inch Coulter Newtonian reflector are listed for sale, complete with accessories such as eyepieces, tripods, finderscopes, and drive controls. Each ad includes a price, condition details, and contact information for the seller.

articles.title: SHUTTLE TESTING CONTINUES
articles.summary: The third full-scale shuttle solid motor test was conducted on April 20th, where a deliberately flawed J-seal flap did not seal, but the first O-ring held, a condition deemed acceptable. The TDRS satellite for the next flight was ready for shipment on May 7th, but the next shuttle launch has been postponed by three weeks to August 25th, with further delays into September anticipated due to an accumulation of minor issues, not technical problems.

articles.title: SPACE STATION FACES BUDGET CRISIS
articles.summary: NASA's space station program is facing a severe budget crisis due to a House resolution that could cut $1 billion from its FY 1989 budget, potentially leading to the station's cancellation. Amidst this uncertainty, NASA is proceeding with plans to select a name for the station in June from options like 'Freedom' and 'Earth Star', and is also studying various crew rescue plans, including the possibility of purchasing an additional orbiter.

articles.title: NEW COMET FLYBY PROPOSED FOR EUROPE'S GIOTTO
articles.summary: Studies suggest that Europe's Giotto spacecraft's high-resolution camera might have survived its 1986 encounter with Halley's Comet. Consequently, a new mission is being proposed for Giotto to explore comet Grigg-Skjellerup on July 10, 1992, with ESA expected to make a decision at its June meeting.

articles.title: JAPAN CONSIDERING COMET FLYBYS IN 1996 - 1998
articles.summary: Japan is considering up to four comet flybys between 1996 and 1998 using its two spacecraft, Sakigake and Suisei, originally launched for Halley's Comet. Sakigake may encounter comets Honda-Mrkos-Pajduskova and Giacobini-Zinner, while Suisei could approach Tempel-Tuttle and Giacobini-Zinner.

articles.title: USAF SELECTS ATLAS CENTAUR AS MEDIUM LAUNCH VEHICLE
articles.summary: The U.S. Air Force has chosen a new version of the Atlas Centaur as its medium launch vehicle, primarily for deploying geosynchronous and defense communications satellites. A contract for 11 rockets, with an option for 20 additional units, has been awarded. Flights are scheduled to commence in 1991, with each launch costing $40 million and capable of delivering 5000-6200 lb to geosynchronous transfer orbit.

articles.title: BY TOM AHL & BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The article details the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) "Star Classes," an outreach program where members bring telescopes to schools for evening astronomy sessions. It highlights several successful events at schools like James Lick High School and Sylvandale School, describing students' first-time telescope observations of celestial objects like Venus, Jupiter, the Pleiades, and the Orion Nebula. The authors emphasize the rewarding experience for volunteers and invite all club members, even those without telescopes, to participate in these educational and community-building activities.

articles.title: Thank you for coming to our star party.
articles.summary: This document compiles numerous thank-you notes from attendees of a star party. Participants expressed their gratitude for the event, highlighting the opportunity to learn about constellations and planets. Many described it as a memorable and enjoyable experience that sparked or deepened their interest in astronomy.

articles.title: BY: JOHN LYNDS FREEMAN
articles.summary: This article recounts an astronomy club star party at Freemont Peak where the author successfully observed Mercury and, more notably, the magnificent globular cluster Omega Centauri low on the southern horizon, deeming it superior to M13. The second part discusses observations and suggestions regarding the club's auction, specifically addressing the difficulty of selling beginner-friendly and high-end equipment, and proposing a catalog for unsold major items to benefit members.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California, featuring guest speakers on various astronomical topics and "Indoor Star Parties" for members to share interests. Meetings cater to diverse interests like astrophotography and telescope making, offering a friendly atmosphere. They occur on the 1st Saturday of each month, with doors opening at 7:45 PM.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Indoor Star Parties are informal gatherings for amateur astronomers to share their passion, discuss topics, and socialize. Attendees are encouraged to bring telescopes and accessories for outdoor observing in the parking lot, while indoor activities include slide shows of astrophotography and past events. These evenings also host SJAA board meetings and an introductory astronomy workshop.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes 'Star Parties' for astronomical observation, typically held on Saturdays closest to the New Moon. These field expeditions vary in location, ranging from sites near San Jose to distant places like Yosemite National Park, with specific details published in the EPHEMERIS.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a highly popular observing site for Bay Area amateur astronomers, located 70 miles south of San Jose. For two decades, enthusiasts have gathered at the 3000 ft. peak during New Moon weekends for deep sky observing and astrophotography, often seeing 50-100 telescopes during summer months. The article also provides detailed directions to the park and lists the officers and board members of the San Jose Astronomical Association, which publishes the 'EPHEMERIS' monthly.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details various membership options, including individual, membership with Sky & Telescope magazine, and junior rates, along with their respective costs. The form provides instructions for submission via mail to the treasurer or in person at a meeting, and specifies that checks should be made payable to "SJAA".
